Attribution.title: General
Attribution.about: BlokDust is a collaboration between Luke Twyman, Luke Phillips and Edward Silverton. Developed in Brighton UK and released in 2016, BlokDust uses the Web Audio API and makes use of Tone.js as an audio framework.

twyman.blurb: Luke Twyman - project concept, design & UI.

phillips.blurb: Luke Phillips - audio development & musical interaction.

silverton.blurb: Edward Silverton - client & server architecture & core development.

Attribution.thanks: Thanks also to Yotam Mann and Brad Sickles.

Tone.name: Tone
Tone.description: A single oscillator. Creates a waveform used as the basis of most synths.

Noise.name: Noise
Noise.description: A noise generator with 'White', 'Brown' and 'Pink' waveform types.

Microphone.name: Microphone
Microphone.description: Captures sound from your device's microphone input. Connect to a Power source & avoid feedback by using headphones.

Sample.name: Sample
Sample.description: A sample player loaded with a Soundcloud track. The track must be creative commons or tagged #blokdust.

Granular.name: Granular
Granular.description: It takes a SoundCloud sample of your choice and chops it into tiny pieces which are used as a sound source.

Recorder.name: Recorder
Recorder.description: It can record the master output and then be used as a sample player.

SampleGen.name: SampleGen
SampleGen.description: Procedurally generates a new audio sample, for creating unique textures or arpeggiated loops.

AutoWah.name: AutoWah
AutoWah.description: Creates a filter sweep in response to the volume of audio input.

BitCrusher.name: Bit Crusher
BitCrusher.description: Creates distortion by reducing the audio resolution.

Chomp.name: Chomp
Chomp.description: A randomised filter with adjustable rate & width.

Chopper.name: Chopper
Chopper.description: A tremolo effect that modulates the volume with an adjustable rate & depth.

Chorus.name: Chorus
Chorus.description: Stereo chorus. Creates a delayed & modulated copy of the audio.

Convolution.name: Convolution
Convolution.description: A convolution reverb which simulates a physical space by using a recorded sample.

StereoDelay.name: Stereo Delay
StereoDelay.description: A stereo delay/echo with adjustable time & feedback.

Envelope.name: Envelope
Envelope.description: An ADSR envelope which alters the volume of sound over time.

Filter.name: Filter
Filter.description: A 'peaking' filter used for boosting or suppressing frequencies.

Vibrato.name: Vibrato
Vibrato.description: An oscillation effect that modulates pitch and playback rate.

Phaser.name: Phaser
Phaser.description: A modulating phaser effect that sweeps through a spectrum of sound frequencies.

PitchShifter.name: Pitch Shifter
PitchShifter.description: Shifts the pitch of any sound.

Reverb.name: Reverb
Reverb.description: A digital reverb with adjustable room size and dampening.

Scuzz.name: Scuzz
Scuzz.description: Frequency modulation (FM) synthesis style effect that can create harmonic and overtone signals.

ParticleEmitter.name: Particle Emitter
ParticleEmitter.description: Fires energy particles. When a particle hits a source block, that source is momentarily triggered.

Power.name: Power
Power.description: Provides energy for sources, particle emitters & lasers. This allows them to be constantly on.

TogglePower.name: Toggle Power
TogglePower.description: When 'on', provides energy for sources, particle emitters & lasers.

Void.name: Void
Void.description: Absorbs any laser beams or particles that collide with it.

PulsePower.name: Pulse Power
PulsePower.description: Provides a short fire of energy for sources, particle emitters & lasers.

Laser.name: Laser
Laser.description: A laser beam that gives energy to sources, particle emitters & other lasers in its path.

ComputerKeyboard.name: Computer Keyboard
ComputerKeyboard.description: Trigger sources using your computer keys arranged into a 2 1/2 octave piano.

MIDIController.name: MIDI Controller
MIDIController.description: Trigger sources using any connected USB MIDI device. Chrome only

SharePanel.SaveWarning: Note: Recorder block samples will not be saved. If you want to share what you've recorded, download the recording from the block's options panel, upload it to SoundCloud, and load it back into BlokDust using a Sample block.
SharePanel.NoBlocks: Create some blocks before you can save & share!

Scenes.Intro: Let's get started by adding some blocks. You can create blocks by dragging them from the top menu.
Scenes.Task: Open up the SOURCE category, and drag a TONE block from it.

Scenes.Intro: SOURCE blocks generate sound, and you can connect EFFECT & INTERACTION blocks to them.
Scenes.Task: From the INTERACTION category, create a COMPUTER KEYBOARD block. Connect it to your TONE block by simply dragging it nearby until a connection line appears.

Scenes.Intro: You’ve just made a basic interactive synth! Now you can play your TONE block using your computer keyboard  - give it a go.
Scenes.Task: Let's make it a bit more interesting, add a CHOPPER block from the EFFECT category and connect it.

Scenes.Intro: You can single-click a block to open up the options panel and adjust it’s settings to your liking.
Scenes.Task: Click on the CHOPPER block and have a play with its settings. Close the options panel when you're done.

Scenes.Intro: Finally let’s look at POWER. We won’t need that COMPUTER KEYBOARD block you made for this.
Scenes.Task: Delete the COMPUTER KEYBOARD block by dragging it into the trashcan, bottom-right of the screen.

Scenes.Intro: Blocks from the POWER category allow you to come up with different ways of triggering sounds.
Scenes.Task: From the POWER category, create a PARTICLE EMITTER block and place it on the marker below your TONE block.

Scenes.Intro: When powered, the PARTICLE EMITTER will fire energy particles at the TONE block, triggering sound as they hit.
Scenes.Task: From the POWER category again, create a POWER block and connect it to your PARTICLE EMITTER block.

Scenes.Intro: Explore and experiment for yourself, or visit the BlokDust Guide for an in-depth Wiki and more tutorials. When you’ve made something cool, click SHARE to generate a unique URL to let others see what you’ve made!
